title: Typhoon Hagibis Slams Into Japan After Landslides, Floods and a Quake
text:
This is a developing news story. Check back for updates.

TOKYO — Typhoon Hagibis made landfall in Japan around 7 p.m. on Saturday, after its outer bands had lashed the country’s eastern coast with heavy rains most of the day and many residents had moved to evacuation centers.

Before it landed, the storm brought landslides, violent winds and record rainfall and flooding. An earthquake measuring 5.7 magnitude also shook Chiba, east of Tokyo, early Saturday evening.

One death was reported in a cyclone in Chiba, and NHK, the public broadcaster , reported that another person died after a landslide crushed his home in Tomioka City in Gunma Prefecture, northwest of Tokyo. Landslides were also reported in Sagamihara, a suburb of the city, and in Shizuoka, a coastal city to the southwest.

The storm made landfall Saturday evening in Ito, a resort town on the Izu Peninsula, also southwest of Tokyo.
description: The storm made landfall  Saturday evening. Many rivers were already at dangerously high levels, and more than a million people had been urged to evacuate.
